title: Diana Davenport, Toorak: Mystery of letter to the editor author
text:
A seemingly rich snob from one of Melbourne’s most exclusive suburbs has shocked newspaper readers with her ghastly view about poor supermarket shoppers.

Diana Davenport from Toorak penned a letter to the editor that was published in today’s Herald Sun newspaper demanding businesses “reward the wealthy”.

“While visiting my local supermarket I was disgusted to find the best parking spaces nearest the door are now reserved for so-called ‘parent and child parking’,” Diana began.

“If you are fit enough to produce offspring, you should jolly well be able to walk across a carpark into the supermarket. The best spaces should be reserved for people with the most expensive cars.

“It is us who are likely to spend the most money in the supermarket, and to have the most shopping to carry back to our cars.”

As Diana’s entitled words quickly spread across social media with observers were unable to believe that such a person could exist. But the mystery doesn’t end there.

A person using the alias Diana Davenport has been a prolific author of letters to Melbourne newspapers for years.

What’s curious is how wildly her worldview seems to have changed of late.

Are you Diana Davenport or do you know who is? Email shannon.molloy@news.com.au

Pranksters are nothing new in the world of letters to the editor, but Diana is a very different beast.

For a long time, the person behind the alias has expressed what appeared to be standard views about politics and social issues.

But in the past several months, Diana has veered into new territory with attacks on bogans and today’s pearler about special privileges for wealthy shoppers.

A search to track down Diana proved difficult as she has used many different contact details over the years.

One address she used actually belongs to the Toorak branch of the Returned and Services League of Australia. Another Bigpond email address is invalid.

And of the two phone numbers used at various times, one is for a Melbourne primary school and the other for a confused gentleman who doesn’t know a Diana.

If the name is familiar to you, chances are you’re a fan of British television drama Midsomer Murders, a character who made one very memorable appearance in 2013.

One of her first letters in February 2015 was to congratulate then Human Rights Commission president Gillian Triggs for “her courage and integrity in the face of ideological vitriol”.

In the years that followed, Diana continued to send a steady stream of letters about Joe Hockey’s exit from parliament, Tony Abbott’s controversial revival of knighthoods and Uber surge-pricing during peak periods.

Yes; ‘Diana’ has been a serial letter writer to The Age for years! — Tracie Winch (@blardyblah) October 15, 2019

Let's all go to Toorak early and take up all the good spaces. — 💧Niki Goodfellow (@nikgoodfellow) October 15, 2019

Definitely a pisstake on entitlement.

And a pretty good one IMO. — Overlady (@Aitch_El) October 15, 2019

Tbh if I were filthy rich I’d probably be that entitled too. — Carly Eastman 💧 (@carlyeastman) October 15, 2019

She seemed to skew left, attacking Mr Abbott’s position on asylum seekers and even comparing him to US President Donald Trump when it comes to climate change scepticism.

“I note with horror that we taxpayers are to fork out $30,000 for a portrait to immortalise ex-Speaker Bronwyn Bishop,” she wrote in March 2016.

And in October that year, she quipped: “So Tony Abbott thinks he can be prime minister again. Of which country?”

But then something unusual happened, when the correspondence took a turn and the normally reasonable and seemingly progressive Toorak resident started to take swipes at the less fortunate.

“You know you’re a bogan when you have four cars that are not mobile and a home that is,” she wrote.

A few months later on December 11, in a submitted letter that wasn’t published, Diana took a shot at a charity initiative designed to bring a smile to the faces of sick kids at Christmas.

“I had the misfortune to be stuck in traffic gridlock caused by the motorcycle rider’s Xmas Toy Run. I have never seen so many middle aged misfits with no teeth and tattoos,” she wrote.

Perhaps taking the rejection as a sign that Diana’s character was pushing the envelope, the author returned to writing fairly down-the-line letters.

She expressed her dislike of Malcolm Turnbull and concerns about the controversial 457 visa.

Then, in January 2018, fork-tongued Diana returned with this: “The only good thing about the one-day cricket at the MCG is that at least it keeps the bogans out of the CBD.”

There were a few more letters about climate change denialists and the Adani coalmine up until Sunday when Diana submitted her now-viral whinge about parking spots for parents and kids at the expense of the wealthy.

The mystery continues.
description: A seemingly rich snob from one of Melbourne’s most exclusive suburbs has shocked newspaper readers with her ghastly view about poor supermarket shoppers.
